title: Equality Plan
legalBasis: LO 3/2007 for Effective Equality of Women and Men; RD 901/2020 on equality plans and their registration; RD 902/2020 on equal pay; EU Directive 2006/54/EC on equal treatment in employment
summary:
Workplace equality between women and men is both a fundamental right and a legal obligation in Spain. The Organic Law 3/2007 for Effective Equality of Women and Men establishes comprehensive requirements for eliminating gender discrimination and promoting equality in all aspects of employment. Companies with 50 or more employees are legally required to negotiate and implement a formal Equality Plan (Plan de Igualdad) with worker representatives. Companies with fewer than 50 employees, while not required to develop formal plans, must nonetheless respect equality principles in all employment practices.

An Equality Plan is a structured set of measures aimed at achieving equal treatment and opportunities between women and men, eliminating existing gender discrimination, and preventing future discrimination. The plan must include specific objectives, quantifiable indicators, defined timelines, and allocated resources. It must address multiple areas including recruitment and selection, classification and promotion, training, remuneration, work-life balance, prevention of sexual harassment and harassment based on sex, and underrepresentation of women in positions or levels where they are significantly outnumbered.

The hospitality industry presents particular equality challenges. Women are often overrepresented in lower-paid service roles and underrepresented in leadership and technical roles such as head chef. Scheduling practices may disadvantage workers with family responsibilities, who are disproportionately women. Sexual harassment and harassment based on sex occur at higher rates in customer-facing roles, particularly those involving alcohol and late-night shifts. An effective Equality Plan addresses these industry-specific issues through targeted measures and regular monitoring.
keyPoints: Companies with 50+ employees must develop, negotiate, and implement a formal Equality Plan
All companies, regardless of size, must ensure equal pay for work of equal value
Gender pay gap audits are mandatory for companies with 50+ employees
Selection and promotion processes must be non-discriminatory and based on objective criteria
Equal access to training and professional development must be provided to all staff
Work-life balance measures must be available to all employees regardless of gender
Prevent and respond to sexual harassment and harassment based on sex through integrated protocols
Underrepresentation of women (or men) in specific roles must be addressed through positive action where appropriate
Equality Plans must be monitored annually and revised every four years maximum
Plans must be registered with the competent labor authority and made available to the workforce

sections.heading: 1. Legal Framework and Obligations
sections.content:
The Spanish legal framework for workplace equality has evolved significantly since the adoption of LO 3/2007, with major revisions through RD 901/2020 and RD 902/2020 that came into force in 2021-2022. These regulations establish detailed requirements for Equality Plans, including mandatory content areas, negotiation procedures with worker representatives, registration requirements, and specific obligations regarding equal pay transparency. Understanding this framework is essential for compliance and for designing an Equality Plan that is both legally sufficient and operationally effective.

The obligation to develop an Equality Plan applies to companies that employ 50 or more workers, calculated across all work centers of the same business entity. The plan must be negotiated with the legal worker representatives — either trade union representatives or elected worker representatives. This negotiation is not merely consultative; representatives have genuine bargaining power over the plan's content. Once agreed, the plan must be registered with the competent authority (typically the regional labor directorate) and its essential content communicated to all employees.

RD 902/2020 establishes specific equal pay requirements that apply to all companies regardless of size. Every company must maintain a job classification system that is free from gender bias, apply remuneration criteria that ensure equal pay for work of equal value, and maintain a salary registry organized by job classifications showing disaggregated data by sex. Companies with 50 or more employees must additionally conduct an equal pay audit as an integral part of the Equality Plan. This audit analyzes the entire compensation structure to identify and explain any gender pay gaps, and to establish action plans to eliminate unjustified gaps.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Timeline and Phases of Implementation
subsections.content:
Development of an Equality Plan follows a structured process beginning with the decision or obligation to create one. For companies reaching 50 employees, the plan development must begin immediately. The process involves: constituting a negotiation committee with equal representation from management and worker representatives; conducting a diagnostic analysis of the current situation across all required areas; setting objectives and designing measures to address identified issues; establishing indicators, timelines, and responsibilities; negotiating the plan with worker representatives; registering the plan with the labor authority; and communicating the plan to the workforce.

The initial Equality Plan must be registered within a maximum of twelve months from the obligation arising (for example, from reaching 50 employees). Once implemented, the plan must be actively monitored with annual follow-up reports evaluating progress against established indicators. A comprehensive review and update must occur every four years maximum, or sooner if circumstances change significantly (such as major organizational restructuring, collective bargaining agreement changes, or identification of serious equality deficiencies).

subsections.heading: 1.2 Penalties for Non-Compliance
subsections.content:
Failure to develop, negotiate, or implement a mandatory Equality Plan is classified as a serious infringement under the Law on Labor Infractions and Sanctions (LISOS), with fines ranging from 751 to 7,500 euros depending on the size of the company and the severity of the violation. Gender pay discrimination is classified as a very serious infringement with fines from 7,501 to 225,018 euros. Beyond direct fines, non-compliance can result in exclusion from public contracts (as equal opportunity measures are increasingly required for public procurement), reputational damage, and difficulty attracting and retaining talent.

Labor inspectorates have intensified enforcement of equality requirements, with targeted inspection campaigns focusing on Equality Plans and equal pay compliance. Inspectors verify that plans have been developed according to legal requirements, negotiated properly with worker representatives, registered, and actively implemented (not merely existing on paper). They also review pay practices and job classification systems for gender bias.

sections.heading: 2. Diagnostic Analysis — Understanding Current State
sections.content:
The foundation of any effective Equality Plan is a thorough diagnostic analysis of the current situation regarding gender equality in the organization. This analysis must examine eight mandatory areas established by RD 901/2020: selection and recruitment, professional classification, training, professional promotion, working conditions including salary audit, exercise of co-responsibility for personal, family and work-life, underrepresentation, and prevention of sexual harassment and harassment based on sex. For each area, the analysis must collect and disaggregate quantitative and qualitative data by sex to identify any imbalances, gaps, or discriminatory practices.

Quantitative analysis involves collecting workforce statistics disaggregated by sex across multiple dimensions: total headcount by sex, distribution by professional category and level, distribution by type of contract (permanent, temporary, full-time, part-time), average salary by category and level, training hours received, promotion rates, use of work-life balance measures, turnover and absence rates, and representation in decision-making positions. This data reveals patterns such as vertical segregation (concentration of one sex in lower or higher levels), horizontal segregation (concentration in certain departments or functions), and pay gaps.

Qualitative analysis explores the lived experiences and perceptions of equality within the organization through surveys, focus groups, and interviews with employees at various levels. This reveals issues that may not be apparent in statistics, such as: whether employees perceive recruitment and promotion processes as fair, whether work-life balance measures are genuinely accessible or stigmatized, whether harassment prevention mechanisms are trusted, and whether the organizational culture supports or hinders equality. Combining quantitative and qualitative analysis provides a comprehensive understanding of current state and identifies priority areas for intervention.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Key Indicators to Examine
subsections.content:
For recruitment: analyze applicant pools by sex for each position category, selection rates (what percentage of female versus male applicants are hired), and time-to-hire by sex. For professional classification: map the distribution of women and men across all job categories and levels, identifying any categories where one sex is significantly underrepresented. For training: compare training hours, types of training, and access to development programs by sex. For promotion: analyze promotion rates by sex and level, and average time-in-position before promotion.

For remuneration: the salary audit must calculate the average pay by sex within each job classification, identify the overall gender pay gap (average female pay as percentage of average male pay), and analyze whether this gap can be explained by objective factors such as seniority, qualifications, or performance, or whether it represents unexplained (and potentially discriminatory) differences. For work-life balance: examine take-up rates of flexible working, parental leave, and other balance measures by sex — often revealing that nominally available measures are used predominantly by women, indicating either different needs or different levels of acceptance.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Identifying Root Causes
subsections.content:
Identifying disparities is insufficient — the diagnostic must explore underlying causes. If women are underrepresented in management, is this due to: lower promotion rates from lower levels, higher attrition at mid-career (often indicating work-life conflicts), lack of access to developmental assignments, unconscious bias in promotion decisions, or limited applicant pools for management positions? Each root cause suggests different interventions.

If a gender pay gap exists, determine whether it results from: women being concentrated in lower-paying job classifications (horizontal segregation), women being at lower levels within the same job families (vertical segregation), different pay for the same job classification (direct discrimination), different access to variable pay components such as bonuses or overtime, or differences in seniority due to career interruptions. Again, each cause requires different remedial measures. The diagnostic should explicitly articulate the hypothesized causes of identified disparities, as these drive the selection of appropriate measures.

sections.heading: 3. Objectives and Measures Across Core Areas
sections.content:
Based on the diagnostic findings, the Equality Plan establishes specific, measurable objectives for each relevant area and defines concrete measures to achieve those objectives. Objectives should follow SMART criteria: Specific (clearly defined), Measurable (quantifiable indicators), Achievable (realistic given resources), Relevant (address identified issues), and Time-bound (deadline for achievement). Measures are the specific actions, policies, or practices that will be implemented to achieve the objectives. The plan must assign responsibility for each measure, allocate necessary resources, and establish monitoring indicators.

For selection and recruitment, if the diagnostic revealed gender imbalances in applicant pools or selection rates, measures might include: using gender-neutral language in job postings and avoiding stereotyped role descriptions, advertising positions through diverse channels to reach balanced candidate pools, implementing structured interviews with standardized questions and evaluation criteria to reduce unconscious bias, ensuring diverse representation on selection panels, and setting targets for balanced shortlists (for example, that finalist candidates include both men and women unless the applicant pool was genuinely imbalanced). The objective might be: 'Achieve gender balance in finalist candidate pools for all positions by Year 2.'

For professional development and promotion, measures might include: establishing transparent promotion criteria and processes that are communicated to all staff, providing mentoring or sponsorship programs to support development of underrepresented groups, ensuring equal access to developmental assignments and stretch projects, analyzing promotion decisions annually for any gender disparities, and implementing succession planning that explicitly considers diversity. Objective: 'Increase the percentage of women in management positions from X% to Y% within three years.'

subsections.heading: 3.1 Work-Life Balance and Co-Responsibility
subsections.content:
Work-life balance measures must be designed to be genuinely accessible to all employees regardless of gender, and to promote co-responsibility between women and men for family and personal care obligations. Traditional approaches that implicitly assume women are primary caregivers perpetuate inequality. Measures should include: flexible working arrangements (flexible hours, compressed work weeks, remote work where feasible) available to all regardless of gender or family status; encouraging men to use parental leave and flexible arrangements through leadership messaging and removing stigma; adapting meeting schedules to respect work-time boundaries; and facilitating return from parental leave through gradual reintegration, maintenance of communication during leave, and ensuring returning employees are not disadvantaged in assignments or development.

In hospitality, where shift work and weekend/evening work are common, work-life balance presents particular challenges. Measures might include: allowing advance notice and input into shift schedules, accommodating school schedule conflicts where operationally feasible, providing compressed work weeks where possible to create more full days off, and ensuring that requests for schedule accommodations are evaluated fairly regardless of gender. The key principle is that work-life balance is everyone's concern, not exclusively a women's issue, and that using balance measures should not negatively impact career progression.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Equal Pay Measures
subsections.content:
The equal pay audit will identify whether unjustified gender pay gaps exist and where they occur. Measures to address pay gaps must be specific and measurable. If direct pay discrimination exists (different pay for the same job), immediate correction is mandatory with retroactive pay adjustments. If pay gaps result from systemic factors such as job classification bias, measures must address the underlying system: review and revise job descriptions and classifications to eliminate gender stereotypes, establish objective and transparent criteria for setting initial salaries and salary increases, ensure equal access to variable pay opportunities such as overtime or bonuses, and monitor pay decisions regularly to ensure consistency.

Transparency is a key element of equal pay. While individual salaries remain confidential, the organization must provide accessible information about pay scales, criteria for pay decisions, and average pay by job category and level. This transparency enables employees to identify potential discrimination and seek redress. The salary registry required by RD 902/2020 serves this transparency function, showing average and median pay by job classification disaggregated by sex, and must be available to worker representatives and labor authorities.

sections.heading: 4. Harassment Prevention Integration
sections.content:
Every Equality Plan must include specific measures for the prevention of sexual harassment and harassment based on sex. These measures often take the form of an integrated Anti-Harassment Protocol (see separate guide G-ROL-010), but must be explicitly referenced and incorporated into the Equality Plan. The rationale for this integration is that harassment, particularly sexual harassment and harassment based on sex, is a manifestation of gender inequality and a significant barrier to women's equal participation in the workplace.

The Equality Plan must establish that the organization has zero tolerance for all forms of harassment, that comprehensive prevention measures are in place (including training, communication, and environmental controls), that accessible and confidential reporting mechanisms exist, that all complaints will be investigated promptly and impartially, and that proven harassment will result in serious consequences. The plan should reference the full Anti-Harassment Protocol and confirm that it complies with legal requirements and has been negotiated with worker representatives.

Monitoring indicators for harassment prevention should include: percentage of workforce that has received anti-harassment training, number of complaints received and their outcomes, time elapsed from complaint to investigation completion, and employee survey results regarding perceptions of safety and confidence in reporting mechanisms. An increase in complaints may paradoxically indicate improved trust in the system rather than deteriorating conditions, so quantitative data must be interpreted carefully in context.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Customer and Third-Party Harassment
subsections.content:
Hospitality workers face particular risk of harassment from customers, a form of third-party harassment for which the employer nonetheless has responsibility to provide protection. The Equality Plan should address this specific risk through measures such as: training staff on how to respond to customer harassment and empowering them to set boundaries, establishing management support protocols so staff can seek immediate assistance when facing harassing customers, making clear that employees will be supported if they must refuse service to harassing customers, and providing security presence or systems (panic buttons, security personnel) in higher-risk environments such as late-night bars.

Customer-facing signage can set expectations, such as 'We treat our staff with respect and expect the same from our customers' or 'Harassment of our staff will not be tolerated.' While such signage cannot prevent all harassment, it signals organizational commitment and provides a reference point for staff intervention. Include questions about customer harassment in staff surveys and exit interviews to assess the scope of the problem and effectiveness of measures.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Addressing Hostile Work Environment
subsections.content: Beyond individual harassment incidents, the Equality Plan must address broader aspects of work environment that may be hostile to women or to men in non-traditional roles. In kitchens, traditionally male-dominated cultures may involve aggressive communication, crude language, or initiation rituals that create hostile environments for women. Conversely, men in predominantly female roles such as front-of-house service may face stereotyping or exclusion. The plan should establish professional communication standards, address any discriminatory 'banter' or jokes, ensure equal treatment in task assignments and opportunities, and foster an inclusive culture where all employees are valued regardless of gender.

sections.heading: 5. Monitoring, Evaluation, and Review
sections.content:
An Equality Plan is not a static document but a living management tool that requires ongoing monitoring and periodic review. The plan must establish specific indicators for each measure, define how these indicators will be measured and reported, assign responsibility for monitoring, and set a schedule for regular review (annual minimum, with comprehensive review every four years). Without rigorous monitoring, the plan becomes merely symbolic, generating no actual improvement in equality.

Monitoring involves collecting the same quantitative and qualitative data used in the initial diagnostic, allowing comparison over time to assess progress. Key indicators might include: changes in gender distribution across levels and categories, evolution of the gender pay gap, participation rates in training and development by sex, promotion rates by sex, take-up of work-life balance measures by sex, complaint and incident rates for harassment, and employee perception of equality and fairness through surveys. These indicators should be reviewed by the Equality Committee (the joint management-worker representative body responsible for plan implementation) at least annually.

When monitoring reveals that objectives are not being achieved, or that measures are not producing intended effects, the plan must be adjusted. This adaptive management approach recognizes that initial measures may be based on hypotheses about causes and solutions that prove partially incorrect, or that organizational or external circumstances may change requiring different approaches. Major revisions require renegotiation with worker representatives, but minor adjustments can typically be made by the Equality Committee within the scope of the agreed plan.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Annual Follow-Up Report
subsections.content:
Produce an annual report documenting progress on the Equality Plan. This report should include: quantitative data on all established indicators, showing trends over time; assessment of which measures have been implemented as planned and which have faced obstacles; analysis of whether objectives are on track for achievement; identification of any new equality issues that have emerged; employee feedback on equality initiatives; and recommendations for any adjustments to measures. The report should be shared with the Equality Committee, worker representatives, and the workforce, and submitted to the labor authority if required by regional regulations.

The annual report serves multiple purposes: accountability for implementation, identification of needed adjustments, communication of progress to the workforce (building engagement and trust), and compliance with legal monitoring obligations. It also provides documentation that the organization is taking equality seriously, which can be valuable defense if discrimination claims arise.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Four-Year Comprehensive Review
subsections.content:
Every four years maximum, conduct a comprehensive review and update of the Equality Plan. This involves repeating the full diagnostic analysis to assess the current situation, comparing results to the initial diagnostic to evaluate overall progress, identifying new or persistent equality issues, updating objectives and measures based on current circumstances, and negotiating the revised plan with worker representatives. The revised plan must be registered again with the labor authority.

This four-year cycle ensures the plan remains relevant as the organization evolves, as labor market and social conditions change, and as legal requirements develop. It also provides natural closure and restart points that maintain momentum — without such defined cycles, equality initiatives can lose focus and become stale. The comprehensive review is also an opportunity to celebrate successes and recognize contributors, building positive associations with equality work.

checklists.title: Equality Plan Development Checklist
items: Constituted negotiation committee with equal representation from management and worker representatives
Conducted diagnostic analysis covering all eight mandatory areas
Collected and analyzed quantitative workforce data disaggregated by sex
Conducted qualitative assessment through surveys, interviews, or focus groups
Completed salary audit identifying any gender pay gaps and their causes
Set specific, measurable objectives for each relevant area based on diagnostic findings
Designed concrete measures to achieve each objective with assigned responsibilities and timelines
Established indicators and monitoring procedures for each measure
Integrated anti-harassment protocol into the plan
Negotiated plan content with worker representatives to agreement
Registered completed plan with the competent labor authority
Communicated plan content and implications to the entire workforce

checklists.title: Equal Pay Audit Checklist
items: Reviewed all job classifications and descriptions for gender bias or stereotyping
Collected complete salary data for all employees including base pay and all supplements
Organized salary data by job classification, level, sex, type of contract, and working hours
Calculated average and median pay by classification and sex
Calculated overall gender pay gap (average female pay as percentage of average male pay)
Analyzed whether pay gaps can be explained by objective factors (seniority, qualifications, etc.)
Identified any unjustified pay gaps that cannot be explained by objective factors
Prepared salary registry in required format showing disaggregated data
Developed action plan to eliminate unjustified pay gaps with specific timelines
Made salary registry available to worker representatives
Included pay audit findings and action plan in the Equality Plan
Established monitoring procedures to ensure pay equity is maintained ongoing

checklists.title: Annual Equality Plan Monitoring Checklist
items: Collected updated data on all established indicators
Compared current data to baseline and previous years to identify trends
Assessed implementation status of all planned measures
Identified any measures that are behind schedule or encountering obstacles
Evaluated whether objectives are on track for achievement within established timelines
Reviewed any equality-related complaints or incidents from the past year
Conducted employee survey or focus groups to assess perceptions of equality
Convened Equality Committee to review findings and discuss adjustments
Prepared annual follow-up report documenting progress and issues
Shared report with worker representatives and the workforce
Identified any necessary adjustments to measures and implemented within Committee authority
Submitted report to labor authority if required by regional regulations

bestPractices: Engage leadership visibly in the Equality Plan — equality must be seen as a business priority, not merely a compliance exercise
Use the diagnostic analysis as an opportunity to listen to employees' experiences and concerns, building trust and engagement
Set ambitious but achievable objectives — overly modest targets suggest lack of commitment, while unrealistic ones invite cynicism
Communicate regularly about equality initiatives and progress, celebrating successes and acknowledging challenges transparently
Provide unconscious bias training for all staff involved in hiring, promotion, and pay decisions
Ensure work-life balance measures are genuinely accessible and that using them does not harm career progression
Address pay gaps immediately — delay erodes trust and exposes the organization to legal risk
Normalize men's use of parental leave and flexible work through leadership example and positive messaging
Treat equality as an ongoing journey of continuous improvement rather than a one-time compliance project
Integrate equality considerations into all HR processes and business decisions, not as add-ons but as core values

glossary.Equality Plan: A structured set of measures aimed at achieving equal treatment and opportunities between women and men in the workplace, legally required for companies with 50+ employees
glossary.Gender Pay Gap: The difference between average pay of men and women, typically expressed as average female pay as a percentage of average male pay
glossary.Salary Audit: Systematic analysis of compensation practices to identify whether men and women receive equal pay for work of equal value, required as part of Equality Plans
glossary.Vertical Segregation: Concentration of one sex (typically women) at lower hierarchical levels and underrepresentation at higher levels
glossary.Horizontal Segregation: Concentration of women and men in different occupational categories or departments, often reflecting gender stereotypes
glossary.Work of Equal Value: Jobs that may differ in content but require comparable levels of skill, effort, responsibility, and working conditions, and therefore should receive equal pay
glossary.Positive Action: Temporary measures designed to accelerate achievement of equality by providing specific advantages to the underrepresented sex
glossary.Co-Responsibility: Shared responsibility between women and men for family and personal care obligations, promoted through work-life balance policies
glossary.Underrepresentation: Situations where one sex constitutes less than 40% of employees in a particular professional group, level, or category
glossary.Equality Committee: Joint management-worker representative body responsible for negotiating, implementing, and monitoring the Equality Plan
